title: Back Pain
description: Back pain is discomfort or pain that can occur anywhere in the spine (neck to lower back). It can be mild or severe, and may affect your ability to move, stand, or sit comfortably.

sections.heading: Common Symptoms
sections.content:
Pain in the lower back, middle back, or upper back

Stiffness in the back, difficulty bending or straightening up

Muscle spasms (sharp, tight pains in muscles)

Radiating pain to the legs (sciatica) or arms

Numbness or tingling in the back, legs, or arms

Pain when standing, sitting, or lying down for long periods

Pain that worsens with activity or movement

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
**1) Muscle or Ligament Strain:**

Overuse or heavy lifting

Poor posture while sitting or standing

Sudden twisting or bending movements


**2) Injury or Trauma:**

Sprains or strains from falls or accidents

Fractures in the spine due to injury


**3) Degenerative Conditions:**

Osteoarthritis: Wear and tear on spinal joints

Herniated disc: Disc between vertebrae slips out of place

Spinal stenosis: Narrowing of the spine, putting pressure on nerves


**4) Lifestyle Factors:**

Poor posture or sitting for long periods

Obesity or lack of exercise

Stress or tension leading to muscle tightness


**5) Medical Conditions:**

Sciatica: Pain running down the leg from the lower back

Scoliosis: Curvature of the spine

Kidney problems (sometimes cause referred pain in the back)

sections.heading: Precautions & Home Care
sections.content:
Rest: Take breaks, especially if you’re lifting or sitting for long periods.

Cold/Hot Compress: Apply a cold pack to reduce inflammation, or a warm pack to relax muscles.

Pain relievers: Use ibuprofen or paracetamol for pain relief (follow dosage instructions).

Stretching: Gentle stretches to relieve muscle tightness, but avoid overdoing it.

Good posture: Avoid slouching; use a supportive chair and lift objects properly.

Stay active: Regular light exercise (eg, walking, swimming) can strengthen back muscles.

Use ergonomic furniture: Ensure your workspace is set up to support your back.

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor
sections.content:
Back pain lasts more than 1–2 weeks without improvement.

Severe pain that prevents you from moving, standing, or sitting.

Pain radiating to legs or arms, especially with numbness or tingling.

Pain after a fall or injury, especially if you suspect a fracture.

Weakness in the legs or loss of control of bladder or bowel function (could be a sign of a serious condition like cauda equina syndrome).

Pain accompanied by fever or unexplained weight loss (could indicate an infection or other serious issue).

sections.heading: Emergency Signs – Go to the ER If:
sections.content:
Severe, sudden back pain after an injury or accident.

Numbness or tingling in the legs or around the groin area.

Loss of control over bladder or bowels (incontinence).

Pain with fever, chills, or unexplained weight loss (could be signs of an infection or cancer).

Pain that doesn’t improve with rest or over-the-counter medications.

sections.heading: Treatment from a Doctor
sections.content:
Physical therapy: To strengthen muscles and improve posture

Prescription medications: Stronger pain relievers, muscle relaxants, or anti-inflammatory drugs

Injections: Corticosteroid injections to reduce inflammation

X-rays or MRI to diagnose the cause of pain (e.g., herniated disc, arthritis)

Surgery in severe cases (e.g., for herniated discs or spinal stenosis)

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Don’t stay in bed for long periods—too much rest can make the pain worse.

Don’t lift heavy objects or do strenuous activities that may strain the back.

Don’t ignore severe pain that radiates to the legs or causes numbness.

Don’t try to diagnose or treat yourself if the pain is severe or long-lasting—seek medical advice.
